subject: Re: [junit] assertTrue(true)
msgSnippet: ... Even brilliant inventors can t think of everything first time. ... It makes plenty of sense to me: various kinds of do-nothing are the zeroes of our
messageBody:
On Tuesday 31 May 2005 20:04, John Smith wrote:
> --- Chris Dollin <kers@...> wrote:
> > Neither.
> >
> > assertTrue(true) looks daft, and the comment won't
> > stop style critics.
> >
> > I have an empty method in my TestBase class(es),
> > called `pass`, which
> > I call. It expresses intent and shuts up the local
> > critic.
>
> If this would be recommended by the JUnit inventors,
> they would have added a method like pass() or
> succeed() in their class TestCase I think.

Even brilliant inventors can't think of everything first time.

> To call a method which does nothing, makes no sense in
> my eyes.

It makes plenty of sense to me: various kinds of do-nothing
are the zeroes of our conceptual arithmetic.

(I appear to be having an attack of Pretentious. It will pass().)

> It silences Checkstyle, but is nonsense nevertheless.

It's certainly not *nonsense*, since it's a perfectly simple
degenerate case, with an obvious and well-defined meaning.

> Of course methods like pass() or
> assertTrue(true) are a kind of documentation.

Exactly; and the more so the former than the latter.

> But this is also a kind of documentation, and can be used
> everywhere, not just for a test:
>
> try
> {
> ...
> }
> catch(NoObjectFoundException e)
> {
> // Ignore
> }

I prefer not to rely on comments for this kind of documentation.

--
Chris "electric hedgehog" Dollin
It's called *extreme* programming, not *stupid* programming.
